content.description: Sit start with two hands and a right heel on the large ledge at the bottom.  Work up to the left using the pinch and slopy ledge.  Once you get to the large right-hand side-pull, there is still a tricky move or two before you can make the top out.
content.location: From Coyote Cave on the Coyote Cave trail, keep following the trail north.  Go past the sweeping turn where Double D Money is.  This boulder is on the east side of the trail. Should be easy to spot.  If you get to Blockhead, you've gone too far.

content.description: Start low with left foot on the tiny chip near the ground.  Work your way up using the arete.  Near the top, swing over onto the face and top out over the crack, not over to the right side on the easy slope.  See photos.
content.location: From Coyote Cave, continue north on the trail for 30-40 feet.  This is just opposite of the big, sweeping turn on the trail.

content.description: Start as shown in photo.  Climb straight up.  Top out.  An easy into to an outdoor boulder since it has the big ledge halfway up.
content.location: From Coyote Cave on the Coyote Cave trail, keep following the trail north.  Go past the sweeping turn where Double D Money is.  Past a project boulder on the east side of the trail.  Blockhead is the next boulder you will come to.  Its right on the trail on the east side.

content.description: Sit start under the small, low, sloping ledge deep inside the cave on the northern-most wall. Finish matched on the chockstone in the roof-crack. A short, but fun, unique problem. Stay off the opposing wall (divided cleanly by a roof crack).
content.location: In the back on the far north wall of the main cave. Look for the chockstone overhead and the slopey ledge about knee high.

content.description: The cavey ridgeline of Fitz north. Some interesting columns, cracks, and roofs, but minimal holds means you've got to be creative to put up anything fun in here.
